columns.text: **a.** **Capital rationing** refers to the situation wherein a highly profitable project lacks the funds needed for it to materialize. There are two different types of capital rationing, hard rationing and soft rationing.

**Hard rationing** occurs if the company cannot take over any project, even if the project is highly profitable, since they no longer have the funds to undertake any project. This occurs in companies that are approaching bankruptcy. In this situation, no matter how high the expected return is, it is still not enough to fund the company. 

**Soft rationing** refers to the situation where in a project needs additional funds so it takes funds from a different department. This means that the company does not lack the capital *per se* but instead they just lack the allocated funds. This can be easily solved by loaning or borrowing funds from another department then repaying the funds after the project is completed.

**b.** As mentioned in hard rationing, bankruptcy is a possibility since the company, no matter how profitable another project is, can no longer undertake any project due to lack of funds. This also puts other potential highly-profitable projects to waste due to the lack of available funds.
**11.6a** In this question, we are required to define capital rationing and to identify the different forms of capital rationing.

**Capital rationing** is the limiting of the amount of funds a company can allocate to new investments. 

The most common types are budgeted capital rationing and opportunity capital rationing.

**Budgeted capital rationing** occurs when a company's managers set a limit on the amount of money they are willing to spend on new projects.Â This limit is based on the company's estimate of how much money it can realistically earn from its current investments.
**Opportunity capital rationing** happens when a company's managers decide to allocate more money to new projects than the company can realistically earn from them.
**11.6b** In this part of the question, it is required that we identify the difficulty that capital rationing creates for discounted cash flow analysis.

The capital rationing makes it difficult to choose between initiatives with varying levels of profitability. A corporation will not be able to fund all of its profitable projects if capital restriction exists. This will result in certain projects not being finished, and the company's total profitability will suffer. Furthermore, capital restriction can cause inefficiencies inside the organization by delaying the completion of several initiatives. Finally, capital rationing might lead to the selection of initiatives with poor profit margins, lowering the company's overall worth.
